The reason the string moves to the other side is that the string momentarily slackens as a result of the tug. If the string were too taught, it would not bind (cause the yo-yo to begin winding) even if it were on that side of the yo-yo. You can catch the yo-yo on a taught string on either side without it binding. It's not exactly symmetrical in how likely it is to bind, but slackness is a big factor and not mentioned in your explanation of binding.

For those who don’t know, this is called “4A” Yo-yo style. 1A is just normal yo-yo. 2A is two yo-yos but only doing loops. 3A is two normal yo-yos that both do 1A tricks. 4A is, as the video depicts, the stringless single yo-yo. And finally 5A. For 5A style the single yo-yo isn’t “attached” to your middle finger, instead, you have a counterweight attached to the end of the string, which means you can leave the string off your hand completely.

In yoyo term , this style is called 4A. There are five different kind of style play of yoyo
1A: the good old traditional trick style with one yoyo tide to one hand
2A: two hands high speed looping
3A: two hands but with string bending together
4A: stating not attached on the yoyo. As seen on this video
5A: similar to 1A but string will not attacking your finger ,instead on a dice or a tiny ball.

This isn't all of yoyoing. There are 5 styles of yoyoing:
1A: String Tricks
These are tricks that involve the yoyo landing on string segments. The yoyo is attached to a string, and that string is connected to your finger.
2A: Dual-handed Looping
This is a style of yoyoing that involves loops, flips, stalls, Around the Worlds, and wraps, but with both hands. One of the more difficult styles, but one of the most thrilling to behold
3A: Dual-handed String Tricks
The most difficult of the 5 main styles. This is the same as 1A, but you have two yoyos instead of one. It is considered the most complicated because a lot of the tricks involve twisting the strings together in some way.
4A: Offstring
One of the easier styles. Commonly mixed up with the Diabolo. THIS IS NOT A DIABOLO. The string is not connected to the yoyo, allowing you to manipulate the yoyo in mid-air.
5A: Freehand/Counterweight
The string is connected to the yoyo, but the string is not connected to your hand. Instead,

That's basically how regular (attached) yo-yos work as well. A properly tuned yo-yo won't bounce up when it hits the bottom, the loop should be loose enough that the yo-yo starts to sleep (that is, just idly spin around on the shaft) when it hits the bottom. Then when you tug on the string (exactly like Ben did on the stringless yo-yo), the yo-yo catches enough of the string that it travels back up towards your hand again.

While the bit about the exponential increase of friction was very interesting, it actually doesn't apply to the specific yoyo that Ben was using. Most high-end yoyos these days have a ball bearing around the axle to allow it to spin for much longer than if it otherwise wasn't there. The world record for longest spin time at the end of the string is actually currently 19 minutes and 39 seconds, something that wouldn't be possible with a simple smooth axle.

You see a piece of string, and what do you think? - It's a piece of string.
You see the spinning part of the yo-yo, and what do you think? - It's a yo-yo without a string.
Since the two are separated, and one doesn't think about a piece of string as a yo-yo without the spool, but one however does think of the spool without a string as a stringless yo-yo, I believe the title is very justifiable.

So one thing you missed about the physics.

When you talk about the catch you mention the Belt Friction Equation.. that doesn't exactly apply. The "axle" in this case is a ball bearing, so it still spins no matter the friction you apply to its outer surface. In this case, it's purely the friction pads that make the trick work. Without those, the yoyo will not be able to generate spin on the throw, or be recaptured.

Just a heads up.

"when Ben tugs the string, he pulls it from one side of the Yo-Yo to the other"

That explanation doesn't make any sense to me. More accurately what must be happening is that when Ben tugs the string, it stops the downward motion effectively crashing the spool and string into each other. This sudden exertion causes friction which binds the string to the bottom of the spool. That spot on the string then turns with the spin of the Y-Yo going up the back side, over the top, and then down the front -- which then causes the spin to be going up in relation to the string. So when Derek goes on to explain that if you watch closely you can see when the string binds to the spool, that isn't correct because he's filming from the wrong side. The moment he describes is when the string coming to the front loops back on itself to start the upward journey, and is a full 3/4 turn after the actual catch takes place.

Great video but I'll have to add something to the belt friction part:
I am pretty sure the yoyo used here (and pretty much most "modern" yoyos) have bearings installed around their axle. So the belt friction happens only between the string and the outer race of the bearing. This race will then start turning with the string but the yoyo and the inner race of the bearing will happily continue to rotate in their direction.
Finally the yoyo does need the friction pads, because only the bearing/axle part cannot grab into the string.
Bang Di is back!

The belt friction equation doesn't apply - the "axle" is a bearing, the string doesn't slip against its surface. Friction comes almost solely from the pads at the side - the gap is wider than the string, allowing to yo-yo to rest on the string without losing significant rotational energy for tricks and stuff, but when there are sufficient wraps of string around the bearing, there's contact between the pads and the string. A common "upgrade" for yo-yos is a bearing with a concave surface, which further reduces the likelihood of contact between the string and the friction pads until one of those "bind" moves, deliberately putting enough string into the gap that the pads and string come into close contact, is performed.
